source_articles.title: I can’t believe how cheap these 5-star income stocks are today… - Yahoo Finance UK
source_articles.body:
2025 has proved another strong year for UK shares. The FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 have risen 19% and 7% respectively. And yet these indexes remain packed with great-value income stocks as we look towards 2026.
The following dividend stocks carry enormous dividend yields at today’s prices. But that’s not all, as they also look cheap based on expected earnings.
Here’s why I think they demand serious attention right now.
HSBC
The HSBC (LSE:HSBA) share price has risen 43% in the year to date. And yet, at £11.18, its dividend yield remains at a robust 4.8%, beating the broader FTSE average of 3.1%.
On top of this, predicted dividend growth over the medium term pushes the yield to 5.4% in 2026 and 5.7% in 2027.
These robust dividend projections are underpinned by HSBC’s Solvency II capital ratio of 14.5%. This is the strongest across the UK banking sector, and at the top end of the bank’s 14% to 14.5% range.
The bank’s Asian focus leaves it exposed to China’s spluttering economy and wider regional issues caused by trade tariffs. So that robust balance sheet helps to at least safeguard HSBC’s progressive dividend policy.
That’s not to say I’m expecting a crisis to come along, mind. Indeed, HSBC’s decision to upgrade full-year profit forecasts in late October underlines its reslience to tough conditions. Net interest income is tipped at $43bn, a target Hargreaves Lansdown analysts describe as “a little conservative and… an easy hurdle to clear“.
I believe HSBC is in great shape to deliver robust earnings and dividend growth over time as wealth levels in emerging markets boom. Yet, I don’t think this is reflected in the bank’s current valuation. It trades on a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 10.2 times.
Aviva
Aviva‘s (LSE:AV.) share price has also enjoyed similarly impressive gains in 2025. At 655.4p, it’s risen 38% in value, driven by signs of impressive resilience in difficult conditions. Just on Thursday (13 November), it projected it would reach £2.2bn of operating profit in 2025, a full year ahead of target.
Yet, despite its price gains, investors can still get excellent value for money from the insurance giant. Its dividend yield for 2025 is 5.9%. This rises to 6.3% for next year and 6.8% for 2027.
Like HSBC shares, Aviva shares also look cheap based on expected earnings. A prospective P/E of 12.5 doesn’t look much to shout about. However, its corresponding price-to-earnings growth (PEG) multiple of 0.5 does.
Any reading below one implies that a share is undervalued.
As with HSBC, dividend forecasts are given strength by Aviva’s impressive financial foundations. Its Solvency ratio was down in the year to September, but remained at a rock-solid 177%. This matters for a company that earns most of profits from the UK, where growth and inflationary pressures are growing.

source_articles.title: 7 Electric Vehicles With Realistic EPA Range Ratings - DAX Street
source_articles.body:
The electric vehicle revolution has brought remarkable advancements in battery technology and energy efficiency, yet one persistent challenge continues to perplex potential EV buyers: the gap between advertised EPA range estimates and real-world driving performance.
While the Environmental Protection Agency’s standardized testing provides a benchmark for comparing vehicles, laboratory conditions rarely mirror the complexities of actual highway driving, varied weather conditions, and diverse driving styles that EV owners experience daily.
Range is considered one of the most important factors when it comes to all-electric cars, and unfortunately, many shoppers have discovered that their new EV falls significantly short of its official ratings when put through real-world testing scenarios.
This disconnect has fueled range anxiety and skepticism about electric vehicle adoption, particularly among those considering their first EV purchase.
However, not all electric vehicles suffer from optimistic range claims. Some manufacturers have engineered their EVs to not only meet but occasionally exceed EPA estimates in independent real-world testing.
These vehicles represent the gold standard in honest range ratings, offering buyers realistic expectations and genuine confidence for long-distance travel.
Each has demonstrated the ability to deliver on its EPA promises under varying conditions, from highway cruising to mixed city-suburban driving.
Whether you’re a daily commuter seeking reliable transportation or an adventure enthusiast planning cross-country road trips, these seven electric vehicles prove that range anxiety doesn’t have to define the EV ownership experience.
1. Mercedes-Benz EQS 450+ SUV
The Mercedes-Benz EQS 450+ SUV stands as a testament to German engineering excellence in the electric vehicle segment, particularly when it comes to delivering on range promises.
This luxury electric SUV doesn’t just meet expectations it consistently exceeds them in real-world testing, making it one of the most reliable range performers in the entire EV market.
On the Edmunds EV Range Test, the EQS 450+ achieved 407 miles, which is a 20.1% improvement over its 339-mile EPA range estimate.
This exceptional performance places it among the elite EVs that actually surpass their official ratings, a rare achievement that speaks volumes about Mercedes’ conservative approach to range claims and the vehicle’s exceptional efficiency engineering.
The secret to the EQS SUV’s impressive real-world performance lies in several key factors. The 2024 model received a larger battery with a maximum capacity of 118 kWh, compared to the 2023 model’s 108.4-kWh pack, providing more energy storage without compromising the vehicle’s already impressive efficiency.
The aerodynamic design, despite being an SUV form factor, helps minimize energy consumption at highway speeds where many EVs struggle to maintain their EPA estimates.
Beyond just range capability, the EQS 450+ delivers exceptional energy efficiency. The EPA expected it to use 39 kWh per 100 miles, but testing showed 32.7 kWh per 100 miles a significant improvement that translates to lower charging costs and fewer stops on long journeys.
This efficiency advantage means owners can maximize their charging sessions and spend less time tethered to charging stations. The interior of the EQS SUV embodies Mercedes’ commitment to luxury, featuring the brand’s signature MBUX Hyperscreen that spans nearly the entire dashboard width, creating an immersive digital experience.
The cabin is whisper-quiet, with exceptional sound insulation that makes highway cruising remarkably serene. Premium materials throughout the interior, spacious seating for up to seven passengers (in certain configurations), and advanced climate control systems ensure that maximizing range doesn’t mean sacrificing comfort.

source_articles.title: The total return for Western Digital (NASDAQ:WDC) investors has risen faster than earnings growth over the last three years - Yahoo Finance
source_articles.body:
The total return for Western Digital (NASDAQ:WDC) investors has risen faster than earnings growth over the last three years
Generally speaking, investors are inspired to be stock pickers by the potential to find the big winners. But when you hold the right stock for the right time period, the rewards can be truly huge. One such superstar is Western Digital Corporation (NASDAQ:WDC), which saw its share price soar 328% in three years. On top of that, the share price is up 110% in about a quarter. The company reported its financial results recently; you can catch up on the latest numbers by reading our company report.
In light of the stock dropping 3.1% in the past week, we want to investigate the longer term story, and see if fundamentals have been the driver of the company's positive three-year return.
While markets are a powerful pricing mechanism, share prices reflect investor sentiment, not just underlying business performance. One way to examine how market sentiment has changed over time is to look at the interaction between a company's share price and its earnings per share (EPS).
During three years of share price growth, Western Digital achieved compound earnings per share growth of 37% per year. This EPS growth is lower than the 62% average annual increase in the share price. So it's fair to assume the market has a higher opinion of the business than it did three years ago. It is quite common to see investors become enamoured with a business, after a few years of solid progress.
You can see how EPS has changed over time in the image below (click on the chart to see the exact values).
We know that Western Digital has improved its bottom line over the last three years, but what does the future have in store? Take a more thorough look at Western Digital's financial health with this free report on its balance sheet.
What About Dividends?
It is important to consider the total shareholder return, as well as the share price return, for any given stock. Whereas the share price return only reflects the change in the share price, the TSR includes the value of dividends (assuming they were reinvested) and the benefit of any discounted capital raising or spin-off. Arguably, the TSR gives a more comprehensive picture of the return generated by a stock. We note that for Western Digital the TSR over the last 3 years was 468%, which is better than the share price return mentioned above. The dividends paid by the company have thusly boosted the total shareholder return.
A Different Perspective
It's good to see that Western Digital has rewarded shareholders with a total shareholder return of 234% in the last twelve months. Of course, that includes the dividend. That's better than the annualised return of 38% over half a decade, implying that the company is doing better recently. In the best case scenario, this may hint at some real business momentum, implying that now could be a great time to delve deeper. It's always interesting to track share price performance over the longer term. But to understand Western Digital better, we need to consider many other factors. For instance, we've identified 1 warning sign for Western Digital that you should be aware of.

source_articles.title: Tech Stocks Outshine As Traders Rethink Fed Cuts - Finimize
source_articles.body:
Nvidia and Microsoft climbed on upbeat outlooks while rate cut hopes faded, giving tech a leg up even as other sectors fell behind.
1 day ago • 2 mins
Join the newsletter that everyone in finance secretly reads. 1M+ subscribers, 100% free.
What’s going on here?
Tech stocks kept defying gravity on Wall Street, with the Nasdaq notching modest gains even as hopes for speedy Federal Reserve rate cuts dimmed and most other sectors lagged behind.
What does this mean?
Investors are still snapping up shares in tech giants like Nvidia and Microsoft, bucking the weaker mood elsewhere in the market. Nvidia’s 1.8% rise was fueled by Morgan Stanley’s upbeat forecast ahead of next week’s earnings, highlighting strong demand and new Blackwell chips. Microsoft added 1.4% after launching its ‘OpenAI for Ireland’ initiative to back local tech startups. Micron Technology stood out too, jumping 4.2% as analysts spotlighted tighter memory chip supply and strong profit prospects. While technology and energy led the charge, materials, communication, and financial firms dragged on the S&P 500, pushing the Dow down 0.7%. Plus, with Treasury yields rising after Fed officials poured cold water on more rate cuts, S&P 500 earnings forecasts—anchored by tech—are now at all-time highs.
Why should I care?
For markets: Tech stocks keep driving the market.
Technology companies are setting the pace, with Nasdaq edging up 0.1% as investors jump in on upbeat earnings outlooks for firms like Nvidia and Micron. Meanwhile, hopes for near-term rate cuts are fading, with December’s odds down to 46% according to CME’s FedWatch Tool. That could put more pressure on sectors that are less resilient if economic growth does slow.
The bigger picture: Earnings strength shapes market momentum.
Record-high forward earnings estimates for the S&P 500 are being driven mostly by tech leaders. Even as gold and silver take a back seat and oil edges up, the market is moving toward areas with real profit power. With Fed officials taking a cautious tone and inflation still a factor, investors are likely to keep favoring companies with dependable results—especially in tech—despite an uncertain policy backdrop.

source_articles.title: Israeli army claims Gazans who arrived in S. Africa on mystery plane had been granted entry - France 24
source_articles.body:
Israeli army claims Gazans who arrived in S. Africa on mystery plane had been granted entry
Israeli authorities said on Saturday that the 153 Gazans flown to South Africa earlier this week had received entry clearance from a third state before take-off. A spokesperson for the Israeli military branch overseeing the operation told FRANCE 24 that the “third country” was in fact South Africa.
To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement.
One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site.
Shimi Zuaretz, a spokesman for COGAT, the Israeli body that runs civil affairs in the Palestinian territories, said the Palestinians had only been allowed to leave Gaza “after COGAT received approval from a third country to receive them”.
Later Saturday, a spokesperson from the same branch told FRANCE 24’s correspondent in Jerusalem, Noga Tarnopolsky, that the third country was South Africa itself.
“This is quite significant because what Israel is contending – via this admission from the spokesperson – is that South Africa invited these Gazans to come, authorised their arrival and then – facing a significant backlash from the population from South Africa and civil society groups who fear that Israel is trying to perpetrate ethnic cleansing in Gaza by sending these Gazans out – backtracked and pretended not to know anything at all,” she said.
“So this is quite a serious change of tone from the Israel army.”
Kept on plane for hours
After landing in Johannesburg on Thursday, the Gazans were kept aboard their plane for 12 hours because they did not have departure stamps from Israel in their passports.
WatchMysterious plane carrying Gaza refugees lands in South Africa
The home affairs ministry finally allowed the passengers to disembark when an NGO said it would provide them with accommodation.
The NGO, Gift of the Givers, told South African media it did not know who had chartered the flight or a previous one that brought 176 Gazans on October 28.
An Israeli official who did not wish to be identified told AFP that the organisation which coordinated the transfer had submitted third-country visas to COGAT for all the evacuated residents.
‘Mysteriously put on plane’
South African President Cyril Ramaphosa told journalists on Friday that it seemed “like they were being flushed out”.
“These are people from Gaza who somehow mysteriously were put on a plane that passed by Nairobi and came here,” he said.
South Africa’s home affairs ministry said 130 of the group entered the country, while the remaining 23 took onward flights to other destinations.
Zuaretz said COGAT facilitates the departure of Gaza residents through Israel to receiving countries, for patients requiring medical treatment, dual citizens and their family members, “or those possessing visas to third countries”.
Israel “bases its decisions solely on requests received from foreign countries”, he added, saying the departure of more than 40,000 Gaza residents had been facilitated since the October 7, 2023 attack on Israel, which sparked the retaliatory war in the Gaza Strip.
South Africa, which hosts the largest Jewish community in sub-Saharan Africa, has largely been supportive of the Palestinian cause.
The government filed a case against Israel with the International Court of Justice in 2023, accusing it of genocide in Gaza.
(FRANCE 24 with AFP)

source_articles.title: RFK Jr.’s Cheer Squad Is Getting Restless - The Atlantic
source_articles.body:
Russell Brand had found his people, that much was clear. Last Saturday, in front of 800 fans in a hotel ballroom in Austin, the comedian doled out praise for Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (whom he called “Great Brother Kennedy”), disdain for the medical establishment (“flat-out evil”), and gratitude for Jesus Christ (“Thank God we have a forgiving God that died for us”). He also told a bunch of dick jokes and, later, called me a Nazi.
After the show, I’d asked Brand for an interview, and he told me that the media are “Luciferian,” and that reporters are Nazis. “Do you really think that?” I asked him. “You’re more like an individual Nazi,” he said, seemingly a concession that I was just following orders. (I didn’t get the interview.)
Brand and his fans had gathered for the annual conference of Children’s Health Defense, the anti-vaccine nonprofit founded in 2018 by the current secretary of Health and Human Services. Kennedy wasn’t there, but the movement’s other headliners were. Brand—who is awaiting trial for rape and sexual assault in the U.K. and has pleaded not guilty—was onstage with Kennedy’s wife, Cheryl Hines, to promote her memoir. Her publisher, Tony Lyons, was there in his role as president of MAHA Action, a nonprofit that holds weekly Zoom calls to galvanize support for Kennedy’s agenda. Also on the scene were Andrew Wakefield, who’s infamous for his discredited 1998 Lancet study on the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine and autism, along with newer adherents such as Bret Weinstein, the evolutionary biologist, COVID-vaccine critic, and podcast host.
Everyone I spoke with at the conference shared a distrust of vaccines and a sense that, after they’d spent years on the fringes of scientific discourse, Kennedy’s rise to power had given them the legitimacy they once lacked. (The theme of the event was “Moment of Truth.”) As Polly Tommey, the program director of the organization’s video-and-audio operation, told the audience: “We never thought Bobby would be health secretary—I mean, come on! We’re in the best place we’ve been for ages!” But what should have been a victory lap at times felt like an attempt to rally the troops, or at least reassure them.
Kennedy’s tenure has been turbulent. In less than a year, he’s sent mixed signals about the benefits of vaccination during a measles outbreak, fired all of the CDC’s outside vaccine advisers and replaced them with his allies, axed the director of the CDC just weeks after she took the job, and stoked fears about prenatal Tylenol use as a cause of autism despite recent conflicting evidence. A string of top CDC officials, including the chief science officer, has resigned, and those who remain say morale has never been lower.
But the Kennedy faithful don’t care about the health secretary flouting institutional norms or sidelining subject-matter experts, because they view HHS, and the CDC in particular, as either useless or corrupt. In fact, some at the conference worried that Kennedy is not acting with enough urgency. (In an email, the HHS spokesperson Emily Hilliard wrote that Kennedy “remains committed to ensuring that all Americans have access to accurate, evidence-based information about vaccines.”)
They want Kennedy to investigate their belief that the government supposedly colluded with Big Pharma to hide the harms of vaccination. In a session on Saturday afternoon, former Republican Representative Dave Weldon, whose nomination to become CDC director was withdrawn in March amid outcry over his criticism of immunizations, called for the creation of an independent body to investigate vaccine-safety data and report only to Kennedy and President Donald Trump. “If it’s in the hands of the CDC, you’ll never get the answers you need,” he told the crowd. During a session titled “The Enduring Nightmare of COVID mRNA Technology,” Sherri Tenpenny, a veteran anti-vaccine activist who once said that one goal of COVID vaccination was to turn people into “transhumanist cyborgs,” called for the mRNA

source_articles.title: UPDATE: Victims identified after rollover crash on Highway 67 S in Biloxi - WLOX
source_articles.body:
UPDATE: Victims identified after rollover crash on Highway 67 S in Biloxi
BILOXI, Miss. (WLOX) - All south bound lanes of Highway 67 are reopened after a fatal crash involving a rollover Friday night.
The crash happened just north of the Highway 15 interchange.
According to Harrison County Coroner Brian Switzer, 61-year-old Ronald Lechner, from D’Iberville, died at the scene. 36-year-old Brittany Hodges, from Ocean Springs, was taken to the hospital where she later died from her injuries.
Switzer said Lechner was driving north in the south bound lane of Highway 67 and hit a vehicle being driven by Hodges, causing his truck to roll over.
Switzer said Lechner’s seatbelt was unbuckled when he hit the other vehicle. He said Hodges’s seatbelt was buckled at the time of the crash.
Officials are still investigating the crash.

source_articles.title: Nikkei Rises As Policy Moves And Company Deals Shape Markets - Finimize
source_articles.body:
Japan’s stock market gained ground after the US resolved its shutdown, while investors weighed profit jumps, big buyouts, and signals from Tokyo on inflation and rates.
3 days ago • 2 mins
Join the newsletter that everyone in finance secretly reads. 1M+ subscribers, 100% free.
What’s going on here?
Japan’s Nikkei 225 ticked up 0.43% to notch 51,281.83, as investors breathed easier after the US sidestepped a government shutdown and positive news on company earnings and deals emerged.
What does this mean?
Investor confidence found its way back to Japanese stocks after the US resolved its shutdown standoff, calming nerves over global market uncertainty. Eyes are now on key US data releases, like September’s jobs report, which could sway expectations for future interest rate moves. But not all uncertainty is gone – the White House has warned some economic data might be withheld permanently, leaving investors in a potential information gap. On the domestic front, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi and Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda are doubling down on supporting moderate inflation and wage growth, especially with producer prices rising 0.4% in October and 2.7% from a year ago, driven by higher costs for farm goods and metals. Company news added even more color: Yamazen dipped 2% on an acquisition, Star Micronics popped on a buyout premium, and Sumitomo Rubber shot up over 13% after reporting a massive profit boost despite softer revenue.
Why should I care?
For markets: Cautious optimism is steering investor sentiment.
Global risk appetite has perked up now that the US shutdown drama has cleared, giving Japanese stocks some breathing room. Still, direction will depend on how upcoming US economic data shapes rate expectations, and whether policy signals stay steady. Robust earnings, like Sumitomo Rubber’s profit surge, are pulling in investor attention, while buyout moves by firms like Star Micronics add an extra jolt of volatility. For now, the mood is upbeat but ready to adjust as new data or policy shifts emerge.
The bigger picture: Japan is walking a tightrope between inflation and growth.
Producer prices on the rise mean inflation concerns aren’t going away, so policymakers in Tokyo are sticking with low rates and pushing for wage increases to keep growth on track. At the same time, healthy dealmaking and strong profits in industries from manufacturing to rubber hint at underlying corporate strength. How Japanese and US policy coordination plays out—and how companies manage rising costs—will be key for markets and the broader economy in the months ahead.

source_articles.body:
EconomyJapan suffers opportunity loss equivalent to 2.6% of GDP from labor crunch
Non-manufacturing sectors fall victim to hiring shortfalls and staff turnover
Lights are turned off on a floor with unused rooms due to staff shortages at a hotel in Nikko, Tochigi prefecture. (Photo by Nanami Sato)
MOTOKAZU MATSUI and GO SAKURAI
November 16, 2025 10:23 JST
TOKYO -- Japan faces significant economic challenges due to labor shortages, and these have resulted in missed opportunities and growth headwinds. The shortfall affects multiple industries, disrupts business operations and increases the likelihood of bankruptcies, highlighting the need to enhance productivity alongside fiscal measures.
